@site.register()
def List(url):
    total_videos = 0
    video_list = []
    next_url = url
    page_counter = 1

    # Get filter value from settings
    filter_value = utils.getSetting('duration_filter')
    if filter_value == 'none' or filter_value == 'all':
        filter_duration = 0
    else:
        filter_duration = int(filter_value)

    while total_videos < 30 and next_url:
        try:
            listhtml = utils.getHtml(next_url, '')
        except:
            return None

        match = re.compile(r'bg-black"><a href="([^"]+).+?<img\s*src="([^"]+).+?<div class="videoDur">([:\d]+).+?<div class="videoTtl" title="([^"]+).*?redirect-link">([^<]+)', re.DOTALL | re.IGNORECASE).findall(listhtml)
        for videopage, img, duration, name, nice in match:
            dur_min = sum(x * int(t) for x, t in zip([60, 1, 1/60], duration.split(":")))
            if dur_min < filter_duration:
                continue
            
            nice = " [COLOR lime][" + nice + "][/COLOR]"
            name = utils.cleantext(name).title()

            contexturl = (utils.addon_sys + "?mode=custom_eroprofile_by_Cumination.Lookupinfo&list_mode=custom_eroprofile_by_Cumination.List&url=" + urllib_parse.quote_plus(BASE_URL + videopage))
            contextmenu = [
                (
                    '[COLOR deeppink]Lookup info[/COLOR]',
                    'RunPlugin(' + contexturl + ')',
                )
            ]
            video_list.append((name + nice, BASE_URL + videopage, 'Playvid', img, name + nice, duration, contextmenu))
            total_videos += 1

        nextp = re.compile('([^\"]+)\"\D*21_73').search(listhtml)
        next_url = BASE_URL + nextp[1].replace('&', '&') if nextp else None
        page_counter += 1

    for video in video_list:
        site.add_download_link(*video)
        
    if next_url:
        # If filter is being used, use page_counter instead of page numbers from the website
        if filter_duration > 0:
            nplptxt = 'Next Page (' + str(page_counter) + ')'
        else:
            np = int(re.compile('(\d+)\"\D*21_73').search(listhtml)[1])
            cp = np - 1
            lp = re.compile(r'(\d+)\"\D+21_75').search(listhtml)[1]
            nplptxt = 'Next Page (' + str(cp) + ' / ' + str(lp) + ')'

        cm_page = (utils.addon_sys + "?mode=custom_eroprofile_by_Cumination.GotoPage&list_mode=custom_eroprofile_by_Cumination.List&url=" + urllib_parse.quote_plus(next_url) + "&np=" + str(page_counter))
        cm = [('[COLOR violet]Goto Page #[/COLOR]', 'RunPlugin(' + cm_page + ')')]
        site.add_dir(nplptxt, next_url, 'List', site.img_next, contextm=cm)

    utils.eod()

https://chat.openai.com/share/e3a05c2e-7.Answer: Sure, you can add two more parameters to the constructor, scale_min and scale_max, to define the range of the scaled values. Here's how you could implement this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the new scale method, first the value is normalized to the range [0, 1] with (value - self._data_min) / self._data_range. Then, it's rescaled to the new range with normalized * self._scale_range + self._scale_min.

ListOfCode.Content:
class ManualLinearScaler:

    def __init__(self, data_min=0.0, data_max=1.0, scale_min=0.0, scale_max=1.0):
        self._data_min = data_min
        self._data_max = data_max
        self._data_range = self._data_max - self._data_min
        self._scale_min = scale_min
        self._scale_max = scale_max
        self._scale_range = self._scale_max - self._scale_min

    def scale(self, value):
        normalized = (value - self._data_min) / self._data_range
        return normalized * self._scale_range + self._scale_min

https://chat.openai.com/share/43ed295b-9.Prompt:
Using docker compose I get the following (using docker container inspect):

"Dns": [], "DnsOptions": [], "DnsSearch": [],

However, the container created this way cannot talk to the internet. When I create the container individually via a QNAP GUI, I get the following (using docker container inspect):

"Dns": null, "DnsOptions": null, "DnsSearch": null,

Not sure how an empty set [] is different than a null, but perhaps it's a nuance. Nor do I know where I can change the one built by compose so it is also null.
https://chat.openai.com/share/43ed295b-9.Answer: In Docker, the "Dns" field in the container inspect output refers to the DNS servers used by the container for name resolution. The difference between an empty set [] and null in this context is significant.When the "Dns" field is set to null, it means that the container is using the default DNS configuration of the Docker daemon running on the host. This typically includes the DNS servers configured on the host machine.On the other hand, when the "Dns" field is set to an empty set [], it means that the container has explicitly configured an empty list of DNS servers. This can cause issues with name resolution, as the container won't have any DNS servers to query for domain name resolution.To resolve the issue of the container created using Docker Compose not being able to talk to the internet, you can explicitly specify the DNS configuration for the container within your Docker Compose file.Here's an example of how you can set the DNS configuration for a container in Docker Compose:[CODE_BLOCK_0]By setting dns: null and dns_search: null, you're instructing Docker Compose to use the default DNS configuration provided by the Docker daemon.Alternatively, if you want to explicitly specify custom DNS servers, you can provide the IP addresses of the DNS servers you want to use in the dns field. For example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In the above example, the container will use Google's public DNS servers (8.8.8.8 and 8.8.4.4) and will search for domain names within the "example.com" domain.By explicitly setting the DNS configuration in your Docker Compose file, you can ensure consistent behavior between containers created via Docker Compose and containers created individually using the QNAP GUI.

ListOfCode.Content:
version: '3'
services:
  your-service:
    image: your-image
    dns: null  # Set DNS to null to use default DNS configuration
    dns_search: null  # Set DNS search to null to use default DNS search configuration

version: '3'
services:
  your-service:
    image: your-image
    dns:
      - 8.8.8.8
      - 8.8.4.4
    dns_search:
      - example.com

https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Answer: Yes, it is possible to assign more than one IP address to a single network interface in Linux. This is typically referred to as "IP aliasing". An alias allows a single network interface, such as eth0, to be used as if it were multiple interfaces, like eth0:0, eth0:1, etc.To add a secondary IP address to an existing interface, you could use the ip command like so:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This command adds the IP address 192.0.2.1 with a netmask of 255.255.255.0 (represented by the /24) to the eth0 interface.To view the IP addresses assigned to your interfaces, you can use the command:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Please note that the addresses added with ip addr add are not permanent and will be removed on the next reboot. To make them permanent, you need to add them to your network configuration file. The method to do this depends on your Linux distribution and its specific networking configuration tools and files.As a side note, this same process can be used to add IPv6 addresses to an interface.

ListOfCode.Content: sudo ip addr add 192.0.2.1/24 dev eth0
ip addr show

https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Prompt: What is the point of ip aliasing?
https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Answer: IP aliasing has several potential uses, including:Host multiple websites on one server: By using IP aliasing, you can host multiple websites, each on a different IP address, all from a single server. This is done by associating each website with a unique IP address, all tied to the same network interface.Network renumbering: If you need to switch your network to a new IP range, you can use IP aliasing to assign the new IPs to your devices while still keeping the old ones active. This can make the transition process smoother and avoid downtime.Load balancing: Some rudimentary forms of load balancing can use IP aliasing. Multiple IP addresses can be used to distribute network traffic among several services running on the same machine.High availability and redundancy: In a scenario where you have redundant servers, if one server fails, the backup can take over the IP address of the failed server. This allows services to continue with minimal downtime.Virtualization and Containerization: In virtualized and containerized environments, multiple virtual machines or containers can share the same network interface, each with a unique IP address.Remember, the use of IP aliasing depends on your specific requirements. Some scenarios benefit from its use, while in others, alternative methods might be more appropriate.

https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Prompt: What if you end up sending packets out on the socket bound to 192.168.1.2. Does it end up sending to both interfaces duplicating the packet, or does it select one at random?

Therefore, each incoming packet belongs to a particular connection and will be delivered to the socket that is handling that connection.

https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Prompt: Is `SO_REUSEPORT` portable across Linux, Windows, MacOS? Are there equivalents? How do you compare it to `SO_REUSEADDR`?
https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Answer: The SO_REUSEPORT and SO_REUSEADDR socket options serve different purposes and their behavior can vary between different operating systems:SO_REUSEADDR: This option allows a socket to bind to an address and port that are already in use. This is useful in scenarios where you want to restart a server quickly after it has been shut down, as it prevents the "address already in use" error that can occur when a server tries to bind to a port that was recently used. This option is widely supported and behaves similarly across Linux, Windows, and macOS.SO_REUSEPORT: This option allows multiple sockets to bind to the exact same IP address and port number. It's used for load balancing incoming connections or packets (for UDP) across multiple threads or processes. This option is not as widely supported or consistently implemented as SO_REUSEADDR.Linux: The SO_REUSEPORT option is available and allows for load balancing. Each incoming connection or packet is delivered to only one of the sockets that are bound to the address and port, not all of them.Windows: The SO_REUSEADDR option behaves like a combination of SO_REUSEADDR and SO_REUSEPORT in Linux. It allows multiple sockets to bind to the same address and port and also allows a socket to bind to an address and port that are already in use. As of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, there is no direct equivalent to the Linux SO_REUSEPORT behavior in Windows.macOS: The SO_REUSEPORT option is available and behaves similarly to Linux, allowing load balancing across sockets.So in short, the SO_REUSEADDR option is more portable and consistently implemented across platforms than SO_REUSEPORT. When using these options, it's important to test your application thoroughly on your target platforms to ensure it behaves as expected.

https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Prompt: How do the 2 options work when using TCP sockets vs UDP sockets?
https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Answer: When working with TCP and UDP sockets, the SO_REUSEADDR and SO_REUSEPORT options behave slightly differently due to the nature of the protocols:SO_REUSEADDRTCP: For TCP sockets, the SO_REUSEADDR option allows the socket to bind to an address and port that are already in use. This is particularly useful when you need to restart a server that has recently been shut down, as it helps to bypass the TCP "TIME_WAIT" state that would otherwise prevent immediate reuse of the same port.UDP: For UDP sockets, the SO_REUSEADDR option also allows multiple sockets to bind to the same port number (and optionally the same IP address, depending on the implementation). This is especially useful when developing applications that deal with UDP multicast, where you may want multiple applications on the same machine to be able to receive the same multicast datagrams.SO_REUSEPORTTCP: For TCP sockets, the SO_REUSEPORT option allows multiple sockets to bind to the exact same IP address and port number, which can be used to balance incoming connection requests among multiple processes or threads in a server application. Note that on Linux, this will only work if the listening sockets are created by different processes or threads, not within the same process.UDP: For UDP sockets, the SO_REUSEPORT option also allows multiple sockets to bind to the same port number (and optionally the same IP address). Similar to TCP, it can be used to balance incoming datagrams among multiple processes or threads. Unlike TCP, though, for UDP this can be used within a single process if desired.Remember that the behavior of SO_REUSEADDR and SO_REUSEPORT can vary across different operating systems. Always consult the relevant documentation and test thoroughly on your target platform to ensure your program behaves as expected.

https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Prompt:
Let's go back to when we have 2 interfaces (interface A and interface B) each connected to different networks, however both interfaces share the same IP 192.168.1.2.

If I have 2 sockets, socket A and socket B. Suppose socket A binds to 192.168.1.2. Suppose socket B binds to 192.168.1.2 but uses `SO_BINDTODEVICE` to only bind to interface B.

How does `SO_REUSEADDR` and `SO_REUSEPORT` affect this and also explain what happens between TCP and UDP.
https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Answer: The SO_REUSEADDR and SO_REUSEPORT options, combined with the SO_BINDTODEVICE option, give you fine-grained control over how sockets bind to addresses and interfaces, and how they handle incoming connections and datagrams.Firstly, SO_REUSEADDR and SO_REUSEPORT affect how multiple sockets can bind to the same address and port. SO_BINDTODEVICE, on the other hand, specifies the network interface that the socket should use for network I/O.In your case, if Socket A binds to 192.168.1.2 (without specifying a device), it will be able to receive traffic destined for 192.168.1.2 on any network interface. If Socket B binds to 192.168.1.2 and uses SO_BINDTODEVICE to bind to Interface B, it will only receive traffic on Interface B, even if the traffic is destined for 192.168.1.2.Here's how SO_REUSEADDR and SO_REUSEPORT come into play:With SO_REUSEADDR, both sockets can bind to the same IP address and port number without getting an "address already in use" error. For TCP, this will typically only work if the original socket is in the TIME_WAIT state (i.e., it has been recently closed). For UDP, multiple sockets can bind to the same IP and port simultaneously.With SO_REUSEPORT, the behavior is similar to SO_REUSEADDR for UDP, but there's an important difference for TCP. For TCP, SO_REUSEPORT will allow multiple sockets to listen on the same IP address and port number and the kernel will balance incoming connection requests among the sockets. However, as of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, using SO_REUSEPORT in conjunction with SO_BINDTODEVICE might lead to unexpected behavior and is not typically recommended.Remember, the behavior of these options can vary between different operating systems and network stack implementations. Always refer to the relevant documentation for your platform and test your code thoroughly to ensure it behaves as expected.As for TCP vs UDP:For TCP, the SO_REUSEADDR option allows a socket to bind to a port that remains in the TIME_WAIT state, and SO_REUSEPORT can be used to balance incoming connection requests among multiple processes or threads.For UDP, both SO_REUSEADDR and SO_REUSEPORT allow multiple sockets to bind to the same IP and port, effectively duplicating incoming datagrams among the sockets.With the combination of SO_REUSEADDR or SO_REUSEPORT and SO_BINDTODEVICE, you can effectively direct and duplicate traffic among sockets and interfaces as needed for your application.

https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Prompt: Without using `SO_REUSEADDR` and `SO_REUSEPORT`, would socket A and socket B end up conflicting over binding to 192.168.1.1 assuming they use the same port?
https://chat.openai.com/share/0b86282d-7.Answer: Yes, without using SO_REUSEADDR or SO_REUSEPORT, if socket A and socket B both attempt to bind to the same IP address (192.168.1.2 as per your description) and port number, there would be a conflict.The first socket to bind to that IP address and port would succeed, and any subsequent attempt to bind a different socket to the same IP address and port would fail with an "address already in use" error.The SO_REUSEADDR and SO_REUSEPORT options are specifically designed to allow multiple sockets to share the same IP address and port under certain conditions, which I described in the previous responses. Without these options, the usual rules apply - only one socket can bind to a given IP address and port at a time.However, in your specific scenario, where socket A does not specify a network interface and socket B does specify a network interface using SO_BINDTODEVICE, it may be possible on some systems for both sockets to bind to the same IP address and port without using SO_REUSEADDR or SO_REUSEPORT.
